Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
August 14, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed or
implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Samantha Way at 517-243-9743.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's
performance within 30 days of the completion of
the probationary period or within 180 days,
whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee's performance annually thereafter.
Seven of fifty-one new employee files did not contain a performance evaluation
completed within 180 days of hire. Two new employees did not have an evaluation
completed, and the other five new employees had evaluations completed late.
CCI Rule 400.4123 Education
(1) An institution shall not admit a child for care
unless an appropriate educational program can be
provided.
On 8/27/25, the facility confirmed they have not been providing youth with an
appropriate educational program approved by the Michigan Department of
Education.
CCI Rule 400.4123 Education
(2) Provision shall be made for an appropriate
education program in accordance with 1976 PA
451, MCL 380.1 to 380.1853. Each resident of
school age shall be enrolled not later than 5
school days after admission and continuously
thereafter.
3

Three of three open youth files reviewed did not have documentation that the
youth were enrolled in an appropriate education program in accordance with the
rule. The facility's policy and procedure manual states "provisions are made for an
appropriate education program in line with 1976 PA 451, MCL 380.1 to 380.1853",
but they have not been following those provisions.
CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio
(4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside
of the direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform
variable interval, eye-on checks of residents. The
time between the variable interval checks shall not
exceed fifteen minutes.
August 2025 bed check logs were reviewed and there were multiple times those
checks exceeded 15 minutes.
CCI Rule 400.4147 Dental care
(2) A dental examination within 12 months prior to
admission shall be documented or there shall be an
examination not later than 90 calendar days
following admission.
One of three open youth files reviewed required a dental exam, and the dental
exam was not completed timely. The dental was due by 8/16/25, but his scheduled
appointment was on 8/22/25.
CCI Rule 400.4153 Shelter care and detention institutions; preliminary
service plans
(1) Within 7 calendar days of admission, a plan shall
be developed for each resident. The plan shall
include all of the following:
(c) The specific services to be provided by the
institution.
Three of three current youth files reviewed did not have a preliminary service plan
documenting the services to be provided by the institution.
CCI Rule 400.4153 Shelter care and detention institutions; preliminary
service plans
(1) Within 7 calendar days of admission, a plan shall
be developed for each resident. The plan shall
include all of the following:
(d) Other resources to meet the resident's
needs.
4

Three of three current youth files reviewed did not have a preliminary service plan
documenting the resources to be provided to meet the youth’s needs.
CCI Rule 400.4154 Shelter care and detention institutions; service
plans.
(1) Within 30 calendar days after admission and
every 15 calendar days thereafter, an institution
shall complete a written service plan. The service
plan shall include all of the following:
(a) The reason for continued care.
(b) Evaluation of service needs.
(c) Ongoing service needs.
(d) How service needs will be met.
(e) Unmet service needs and the reasons
those needs are unmet.
Three of three current youth files reviewed did not meet the requirement of this
rule. One youth file did not have an assessment completed within 30 days of
admission. The other two youth files did not have reports completed every 15
calendar days after the 30-day report. Therefore, they did not meet the provisions
of subsections (a-e).
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge:
(b) A brief summary or other documentation
of the services provided while in residence,
including medical and dental services.
(c) An assessment of the resident's needs that
remain to be met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the
facility after discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and
dental follow up that is needed, have been
reviewed with the resident and with the parent
and with the responsible case manager.
Four of four closed youth files reviewed did not have a discharge plan which
documented the requirements in subsections (b-e) of the rule.
5

CCI Rule 400.4506 Fire drills and telephone
(1) There shall be quarterly emergency fire drills for
each staff shift. Two of the drills shall include
evacuations, unless approved by the department, in
writing, as clinically contraindicated. Where a
facility has a 24-hour staff shift, the emergency drills
shall be conducted at different times of the day and
night. Written records shall be maintained for each
drill indicating the date and time of the drill and,
where evacuation was a part of the drill, the
approximate evacuation time.
The facility did not complete quarterly fire drills on each shift as required. For
example, all fire drills completed at Besser and Klare Cottages from January-April
2025 were completed during 2nd shift, and all fire drills completed at Mary
Katherine from January-July 2025 were completed during 1st shift.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• The facility was provided with feedback and guidance for CAP
requirements and completion.
• Fire drill logs must document whether an evacuation took place or not.
Evacuations are required for at least 2 out of 4 quarterly drills. Evacuation
times must be documented.
• Fire drill logs must follow the same shift timeframes (Youth Care
Professional shifts) to ensure compliance.
• The facility can complete monthly fire drills, but they need to still follow the
quarterly requirements of completing them on different shifts. For example -
have a rotation such as 1st shift in January, 2nd shift in February, 3rd shift
in March and continue from there.
• Performance evaluations for new staff must be completed within 180 days
of hire. They cannot cover a timeframe of 180 days but be completed after
the 180-day mark.
• Provided guidance to the facility regarding training logs for new and
seasoned staff. Training logs must include hours completed and there must
be an easy way to discern how many hours of training staff completed. The
tracking spreadsheet is a great tool, but needs to include more detail and
information.
• Provided guidance and information regarding appropriate education
programs for youth. Youth must be enrolled in a program approved by the
Michigan Department of Education.
6

• Prior technical assistance was provided to the facility regarding preliminary,
initial and ongoing service plans on 8/1/24, 9/16/24, and 1/9/25. However,
the facility did not follow the guidance provided and received violations for
Rule 153 and 154 as a result. Technical assistance was again provided to
the facility regarding service plan timeframes and requirements.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Provided the facility with feedback and suggestions related to
communication and staff meetings based on information learned from staff
interviews.
• Provided the facility with guidance surrounding completion of annual
central registry clearances. The CWL-4624 is only required prior to initial
hire and if a staff discloses CPS involvement while employed. For annual
central registry checks, the CWL-1929 should be completed and sent to the
local DHHS office for processing. The DHHS office will then send the CWL-
1910 back to the facility, which shows the results of the check.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The first
CAP (approved 10/25/24) was a result of the facility's 2024 Renewal Inspection
(approved 9/4/24). The facility received a repeat violation for Rule 113(1)(i)
regarding central registry clearances and a violation for Rule 120(1)(c) for hiring a
supervisor of direct care who didn't meet the requirements of the rule. To mitigate
these issues, the facility created an employee file audit form which required review
and approval by the assistant director prior to the employee being hired. The
facility successfully implemented and completed this CAP.
The second CAP (approved 7/3/25) was a result of SIR#2025SIC0000680 (dated
6/2/25) which had a violation for Rule 109(1)(c) due to a staff not following the
facility's code of conduct policy. The facility placed the staff on suspension and
ultimately terminated them. The facility committed to re-training staff on various
topics and policies including mandated reporter, confidentiality, code of conduct,
prevention and reporting sexual abuse & harassment, employee handbook,
7

professionalism, etc. The facility is also having staff sign off on some of these
policies.
The third CAP (approved 8/20/25) was a result of SIR#2025SIC0000803 (dated
8/6/25) which had a violation for Rule 142(1)(a) due to a staff not following the
facility's medical policy. The facility placed the staff on suspension and ultimately
terminated them. The facility committed to conducting a workshop on incident
report training, restraining on medical reporting and incidents, and more oversight
from shift leaders to ensure incident reports are completed and submitted.
Financial Overview
The facility's budget and 2024 financial audit were reviewed, and no concerns were
noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) reported the program has substantially blossomed
regarding nutrition, education, and daily living since November 2024. CA reported
nutrition and food has become more personalized, and they request youth
feedback. CA reported the hardest part has been hiring bilingual staff to fill their
open staff positions.
CA reported the program officially implemented an employee audit tool checklist
that included the Assistant Program Director as a second audit to the onboarding
candidate. If a deficiency was found, the program provided a new start date to the
candidate. That process ensured this rule and other new hire requirements were
completed before the start date. This has been successful in ensuring compliance.
CA reported this process also ensured no candidates were hired who didn't meet
the qualifications and requirements of their position. On 5/8/25 the program
immediately implemented staff code of conduct and professionalism policy training
for six months. The program also held a refresher training on Child Abuse and
Mandated Reporter, Confidentiality, Code of Conduct, Prevent and Report of
sexual Abuse and Harassment, and Employee handbook acknowledgment policies,
and take the ORR reporting and boundaries training. These CAP activities have
presented the staff with continued policy and reporting refreshers to ensure policy
is known and understood. On 6/19/25, The program implemented refresher incident
reporting training during monthly All-Staff Meetings. These refreshers allow staff to
routinely hear the procedures and allow leadership to perform knowledge checks.
On 6/13/25, the Director of Operations, provided the program with the results of her
unannounced monitoring visit on 5/25/25. This program self-assessment resulted in
program improvements and/or oversight regarding Rules 136, 138, 149, and 506.
8

Staff and Youth Interviews
Director reported they're seeing longer lengths of stay for youth due to changes in
sponsorships and the federal government, therefore they're exploring alternative
ways for youth to achieve their education requirements through online
programming and GED achievement. Director reported they've seen strides in
basic foundations of care for the youth since January and they're continuing to
improve all services they provide. They improved nutrition for the youth and
obtained youth input during youth council to ensure they're getting the food they
want and not so much food is wasted. They did an internal audit with the Director of
Safety and Director of Operations, which gave them a baseline of where they're
currently operating so improvements can be made going forward. Staff morale is
increasing, but there are still challenges at times. Staff have a passion for what they
do, and it shows when they're working. They're focusing a lot on the hiring process.
The program is currently approved by ORR to fill 40 youth beds, but once staffing
increases, they hope to increase to approval for 50 beds.
Assistant Director reported it has been incredible to see the effects of smoothing
processes out to becoming a more well-oiled machine. She reported they're
focusing a lot on training right now. She reported the two CAPs they've had have
reorganized them to have a better standard of more refresher trainings and critical
reminders regarding reporting, standards of conduct, etc. She reported this helps
the staff to have these topics on their mind more often, so compliance can improve.
She reported they are constantly telling staff over-reporting is better than not
reporting. She reported they are seeing the progression of improved
communication in that regard. She reported they have struggled hiring bilingual
staff, so they are working on expanding their recruiting efforts to have more
success.
Teacher Assistant (TA) reported she loves seeing the students and bonding with
them. She enjoys seeing the youth learn English, and in turn, they're teaching her
Spanish. TA reported training was really good and she learned a lot. She feels
supported by her team as well as upper management. She feels comfortable
reaching out and asking questions or providing feedback as necessary. TA
reported communication could be improved by preparing in advance if youth need
to leave, have appointments, etc. She said recently a few youths weren't in class
and she wasn't aware they were off campus, so it was confusing when she began
teaching. She reported the staff are great with the youth and she's really impressed
by the way youth and direct care staff bond with each other and build their
relationships. TA reported it's a stressful situation for the youth because they don't
know their plans or where they'll go next, so the patience they have while placed at
the facility is amazing. She reported staff are great at comforting and supporting
youth, so they have reassurance while at the facility.
9

Clinician reported she likes the culture, dynamic and purpose of working for the
organization. She reported the support from the clinical team and relationships with
staff, and her supervisor are going well. She reported training was good, but a little
chaotic because the trainer was still in training, so her training lasted longer.
Clinician reported she feels comfortable providing feedback and asking questions.
Clinician would like to see communication be improved if youth are at activities or
visits because clinicians have a limited time to meet with youth, and when they
don't know what youth are doing, it makes it hard to schedule.
Shift Leader (SL) reported things are going well at the facility. He reported training
went well, but ongoing training is necessary. He reported he feels supported in his
position. He reported everyone is a team, but communication needs to improve to
ensure the team functions correctly. For example, there needs to be improvement
regarding communication when advocates come to meet with youth, there are
meetings with the consulate, appointments for youth, etc. He reported he feels
comfortable giving feedback, voicing concerns, and asking questions.
Youth Care Professional 1 reported things are going well at the facility. She loves
being involved with the youth and she's learning a lot of Spanish, which has been a
fun aspect of working here. She reported communication could be improved
regarding knowing about things before they happen. For example, there are
progress notes for each shift, but sometimes things happen throughout the day that
don't end up in the progress notes. Therefore, if youth are reactive or having a
tough time, people don't know why. She feels supported in her position and feels
they provided the most thorough on the job training she's ever been through. She
reported monthly staff meetings are productive, and she feels she can provide
feedback, concerns and ask questions as needed.
Youth Care Professional 2 reported she likes working at the facility, likes her team
and likes leadership. She reported she loves working with the kids and learning
about their different backgrounds and personalities. She reported communication
could be improved. For example, information will be provided to one person, then
will skip over the direct care staff, and be told directly to the youth. She feels direct
care staff don't get the information needed, especially if their shift leader isn't
present that day. She reported sometimes they aren't notified of youths'
appointments, court hearings, etc. which is frustrating. She reported she feels
supported in her role but sometimes she feels she doesn't know what's going on
due to the lack of communication. She reported training went well initially and they
have refresher trainings every 2 months, which is helpful. She reported she feels
comfortable providing feedback, concerns and asking questions as needed.
Youth reported staff treat them well and they have staff they can talk to if needed.
Youth reported the food is good and they get enough to eat. They all reported
feeling safe at the facility and did not have any concerns or things they didn't like.
10

Description of Agency Walk Through
A walkthrough of Mary Kathrine, Klare (school building), and all 9 cottages occurred
on 8/14/25. There was no safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
